description: From Middle English firken, ferken (“to proceed, hasten”), from Old English fercian (“to bring, assist, support, carry, conduct, convey, proceed”), from Proto-West Germanic *farikōn, from Proto-Germanic *farikōną, frequentative of Proto-Germanic *faraną (“to travel, fare”). Akin to Old English faran (“to fare, go”), English fare; if so, equivalent to fare +‎ -k. Cognate with Old High German fuora (“benefit, sustenance, support”), Swabian fergen, ferken (“to bring, dispatch”).

verbs.description: firk (third-person singular simple present firks, present participle firking, simple past and past participle firked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To carry away or about; carry; move.

examples: 1599,  William Shakespeare,  “The Life of Henry the Fift”, in  Mr. William Shakespeares Comedies, Histories, & Tragedies […] (First Folio), London:  […]  Isaac Iaggard, and Ed[ward] Blount, published 1623, →OCLC, [Act IV, scene iv]:I'll fer him, and firk him, and ferret him.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move quickly; go off or fly out suddenly; turn out.
